title: Will Apple's end-of-day market capitalization exceed $1 trillion before 1 January 2018?
preds: In order for Apple to reach a market capitalization of $1 trillion by January 1, 2018, its value would have to increase by about 11 percent in the next two weeks. An increase of that magnitude will only occur if there is a significant news event that triggers it, the most likely of which would be a higher than expected earnings report. Given that Apple does not report earnings again until January 30, it seems highly unlikely that the company will reach a market cap of $1 trillion by the first of next year.

While AAPL is up ~52% YTD and has a market cap as of 11/9/17 of $901 billion (per Bloomberg) the likelihood that it reaches $1 trillion in market cap by Jan 1 2018 is low in my opinion. That market cap would imply a stock price of $194.77 if no additional equity shares are issued (currently there are approximately 5,134,312,000 shares outstanding per Bloomberg) which is 10.85% higher than it's current price of $175.78. Without significant positive news driving the stock higher I see a move of this magnitude as unsubstantiated. No new earnings announcements will be released between now and then. In addition, I believe the broader market will stagnate headed into the last month and a half of the year as corporate tax reform still faces significant hurdles in my opinion. Apple faces significant asymmetric risk with tax reform as a large portion of cash on their balance sheet is held offshore (http://fortune.com/2017/10/31/trump-tax-reform-apple-multinational-companies/). Additionally, I think there is some risk that AAPL faces some backlash for tax avoidance that they've been in the news for. This could lead to some backlash as well as fines of some sort as penalties. I haven't followed that aspect too closely but I don't think that'd be a book for the stock price if it persists in the news.  To hedge myself slightly on a this position I'll assign a 5% probability and adjust as we move forward if my thoughts do/don't play out.

Apple will not release earnings again before January 1, 2018.  Apple shares have climbed almost 50 percent this year on expectations for the iPhone X.  Any delays, issues, or poor reviews of the iPhone X will prevent Apple from reaching 1 trillion.  Apple has predicted records sales of $84 billion for Q4 and the stock gained nearly 4% on rollout.  The stock price would need to get to nearly $200. Apple gains about $25 in stock price every six weeks (currently at $174, 8 weeks out)

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-apple-stocks/apple-market-value-we-may-need-a-bigger-chart-idUSKBN1D20BQ?utm_source=Sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=US%20Reuters%20News%20Now%202017-11-02&utm_term=US%20Reuters%20News%20Now Apple’s stock has risen about 26 percent per year on a compound basis since the start of 2007, a trajectory that - based on its current shares outstanding - could see it reach a market capitalization of $1 trillion in mid-2018. The mean price target of 37 financial analysts covering Apple stands at $176.70, equivalent to a market value of $913 billion. At least four analysts have target prices for Apple that put its market value above $1 trillion. Drexel Hamilton's White, the most bullish among Apple analysts tracked by Thomson Reuters, has a target price of $208, equivalent to a market capitalization of $1.074 trillion. (reut.rs/2z5egB9) No analysts recommend selling Apple shares, but among the seven with “hold” ratings, one of the least enthusiastic is Rosenblatt Securities analyst Jun Zhang, with a $140 price target. Initial reviews of the iPhone X called it the best iPhone yet, although some reviewers pointed out potential glitches in FaceID, the company’s new face recognition system.
~~~~~~~

Apple would have to reach about $193.6 per share at current shares outstanding. One standard deviation from 164 using historical volatility at 22.5% and with 80 trading days left, there's a 7.73% chance that AAPL's share price will cross that threshold. This assumes today's price as the mean, which is unrealistic given it's a 52 week high. On the other hand, PE ratio seems healthy in comparison to other tech companies. Per CNN 23 analysts recommend buying, others 13 hold or outperform the market and only 1 sell. http://money.cnn.com/quote/forecast/forecast.html?symb=aapl Apple's share price would also have to increase 19% as of today, and it's quarterly growth is 12.76% Apple's strongest quarter appears to be Q1, so if trends hold, it might reach about $183 per share optimistically (estimated 36% chance) and surpass $193 with something between an 8-16% chance assuming similar growth. Will update as I gain more certainty.
Updating for the passage of time.

In the past year, AAPL has spent much more time time in the "overbought" condition, according to the Williams %R indicator, than in the "oversold" condition. Over the first six months of the year there has been a 24% increase with a high above 30%, but I think the broader market has two headwinds going into the second half of the year:
1) There is a real possibility that corporate tax reform that has been claimed to be part of the reason for the increase in S&P will not happen this year. 
2) There is a roughly 30% possibility of another rate increase from the fed this year which tends to decrease market prices. https://www.investing.com/central-banks/fed-rate-monitor

The main force behind the US stocks in general are foreign buyers running away from mostly sovereign debt crises in their respective domestic markets as well as lack of confidence in the future of EU and other regions. This also applies to the domestic US investors at least those who are allowed by law to invest in to equities instead of bonds. So far I have been talking about the big guys the institutional investors. But wait for the retail chaps to enter the market and this alone could bring the market cap to 1 trillion level. Also any major disaser abroad like say Merkel loosing elections (seems unlikely but look at the Britain's late elections?!) would most certainly deteriorate confidence of investors globaly and thus send their capital to US market. On the flip side historicaly there has been I think only 1 company that reached a market cap of over a trilion $ (adjusted for inflation) i.e. Petro China. Therefore I am starting st 9% and will wait for world events to unfold.

I like Anneinak's forecast. Smart, logical and concise. A bit negative indeed, but I'm a fanboy. So I'm optimistic. What I have found in the past 3 major drops of Apple's stock are people predicting even more disasters. Granted Jobs is not the head of the company and no longer on this planet, Yet, I believe that Apple has persevered and will continue to find it's place in this future of ours.  Things against the growth line that Anneinak speculates could also include:
- an already high book value ratio 
- rehashing the same type of products can put a chill on expectations
- no new real innovations coming from Apple What could happen?
- A late September/October announcement of a new phone, new worthy product updates
- better yet, a new, real innovation - though we'd probably hear some mutterings about it now.
- a major acquisition (it is sitting on $250B in cash - http://www.cnbc.com/2017/05/02/apples-cash-hoard-swells-to-record-256-8-billion.html) It's market cap has grown. In my calculation I can see it rising easily to $890B by end of year. (https://ycharts.com/companies/AAPL/market_cap) But, having said that I bet it will break that Trillion dollar mark. I too am learning more about stocks. I'm by far not an expert.
based on amount of volume in either direction.

One of my reasons for participating on GJO is for the incentives it creates to learn about new things.  I know absolutely nothing about this kind of question, but since I am an Apple person,  I thought I'd give it a try.  In other words, forecasters, do not follow me on this! I see that the current market valuation is $750,584 @ $142.84.
The price per share on 1/3 was $116.75
So, if I understand it correctly, the share price has increased 22% since 1/3.
122% of $750,584 is $915,713, short of $1T. That assumes straight-line growth.  What is normal growth for Apple? What could cause the growth line to point downwards?  flatten?  or develop a greater or lesser slope?   
1) The introduction of new & popular products.
2) Legal problems
3) loss of market share
4)  a failed product launch What are the market dynamics when a company gets so large?   Does a high growth rate become more difficult to sustain or does it feed on itself? I'm starting off with a mildly negative forecast:  negative because it seems like more than 22% growth is expecting too much but only mildly negative because I know so little.   I'm looking forward to reading the posts of more knowledgeable people!

"Yes" would require ca 33% growth in 135 trading days. Raw base rate would be high - more than 50% of days since 2005 have seen such growth. Taken in context: June, just peaked, end of Trump rally, inflation not picking up. Unlikely.

Tech stocks have been shaky for a couple of days, but 1 January is still a fur piece down the road.  They'd still need pretty spectacular numbers for the next few months to make this number.  Stay tuned.
